{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3422576,"name":"Biniza Vázquez","username":"Bini","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bini/{size}/191857_2.png","created_at":"2024-09-11T05:06:28.065Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone! Biniza Vazquez from Mexican team Imperator 5887. I am currently introducing myself to swerve drive programming as an off season initiative for my senior year (we already have a base code, but my lead mentor encouraged me to come up with an entirely new code of my own). We have a SwerveX with NEOS, which we don’t have access to temporarily for educational purposes , so for now, I am trying to simulate my code in order to learn about kinematics and control.
Recently, I encountered some issues with visualizing my module states on Advantage Scope. I followed some steps from this Youtube tutorial in order to do so: https://youtu.be/OvGzSTomdGE?si=X_und6YL575NzSiC

I am logging them by pushing my module’s getAngle() and getSpeedMetersPerSecond() methods in my SwerveSubsystem periodic. Whenever I try to simulate driving with my keyboard joysticks, it seems to be a problem with how my module states are being logged or passed into my modules:

  1. Back drive axis goes forward (and seems to be added to forward motion vector).
  2. Turn axis does not seem to rotate (minimal turn being printed on my console)

I have tried things like changing my rotation and kinematics units, as well as minimal PID gains based on my team’s current code.

I reach out to you guys looking for some help to debug , but more than anything else, to learn and really understand a little more about the basic operation of swerve kinematics

Thank you very very much in advance!!! I am open to any advice you’d like to give
happy off season time!!

Here’s the link to my repo: GitHub - binivazqua/mySwerveDive: My entire swerve drive code from scratch. Trying to gather everything I've learned from my team and others to finally try to understand what's going on behind a swerve drive chassis.

Our team has the same setup! We got it working last year but we’re still working out some issues. We did try custom code, but ultimately found that the swerve drive library Y.A.G.S.L. worked great for us. If you are interested in an education experience with learning swerve, making a custom solution is a great way to do it! But, if you’re just interested in getting it up and working quickly, I would strongly recommend looking into YAGSL.

Also, YAGSL’s example project can run simulations out of the box and you can see all of the data it logs. You can build upon YAGSL too, so for example if you wanted a slow mode and a fast mode, it’d be super easy to implement.
